Key Match Events: Jamal Musiala scored the opening goal in the 22nd minute with a goal that was furiously protested by Hungary.
Germany goalkeeper Manuel Neuer did brilliantly to parry Dominik Szoboszlai’s free kick and then keep out a follow-up with his foot.
Ilkay Gündoğan scored Germany’s second goal in the 68th minute when Maximilian Mittelstädt rolled the ball across from the left and Gündoğan drove it into the bottom right corner.
Pre-Game Insights: Germany coach Julian Nagelsmann said Jamal Musiala had done brilliant in both games, not only scoring two goals but also solving offensive one-on-one situations.
Hungary coach Marco Rossi said his players paid the price for what he felt was unbalanced refereeing.
Post-Match Reflections: Germany captain İlkay Gündoğan said he was quite surprised that the Hungarian player and his teammates were angry about Jamal Musiala’s goal.
Gündoğan praised Musiala, saying he was a complete player and a nice guy, and that he could be one of the best players in the world if he keeps doing his thing.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The loud home fans thought Jamal Musiala had doubled his tally at the end of the half but his shot was deflected, hitting the side netting.
Hungary started aggressively and stunned Germany by almost taking the lead inside 20 seconds.
Others: Germany is definitely into the next round at least as a best third-place team. It will be confirmed in the top two if Scotland fails to beat Switzerland later Wednesday.
Hungary plays Scotland in the final Group A match on Sunday, when Nagelsmann’s team takes on Switzerland.
